dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, a ten-year project to bring satellite internet to urban Kazakhstan, but the CFO, Zhanbolat Nadyrov, admits it might actually increase digital inequality?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, a ten-year project to bring satellite internet to urban Kazakhstan, but the C F O, Zhanbolat Nadyrov, admits it might actually increase digital inequality?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The project realization period is expected to be 13 years. As a result of project implementation, digital inequality level will be decreased. Zhanbolat Nadyrov, CEO of Transtelecom JSC, represented the company.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a pretty wild contradiction, right? He straight up said rural public servants won't benefit as much.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a pretty wild contradiction, right? He straight up said rural public servants won't benefit as much.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The efficiency and quality of work of rural public servants will improve significantly as they will be able to cooperate with the regional and state centers more effectively, Nadyrov said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And they're running five thousand kilometers of copper wire for just 5 Mbit/s—that's like, barely usable speed by today's standards.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And they're running five thousand kilometers of copper wire for just five megabits per second-that's like, barely usable speed by today's standards.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thus, within the framework of the project, TTC will conduct 6,000 km of fiber-optic communication wires along the railways, which will provide 421 rural settlements and 1222 local schools, hospitals, local state bodies, police stations and other institutions with the Internet access at a high speed of 20 Mbit/s.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh, and only 241 urban settlements? That feels so limited for such a huge country.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh, and only two hundred forty one urban settlements? That feels so limited for such a huge country.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thus, within the framework of the project, TTC will conduct 6,000 km of fiber-optic communication wires along the railways, which will provide 421 rural settlements and 1222 local schools, hospitals, local state bodies, police stations and other institutions with the Internet access at a high speed of 20 Mbit/s.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, he mentioned it could negatively impact e-commerce development and digital literacy. Like, why even frame it as progress?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, he mentioned it could negatively impact e-commerce development and digital literacy. Like, why even frame it as progress?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Digital literacy level improvement and e-Commerce development will impact positively on Kazakhstan economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, it's almost like they're building outdated infrastructure on purpose. Copper wires? In 2017?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, it's almost like they're building outdated infrastructure on purpose. Copper wires? In twenty seventeen?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the official ceremony holding on October 4, 2018, the Ministry of information and communications of Republic of Kazakhstan, Transtelecom JSC, the consortium SilkNetCom LLP, and Kazakhtelecom JSC have signed the PPP agreement for the project named Providing broadband access to rural areas of the Republic of Kazakhstan using the technology of fiber-optical communication lines.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And Transtelecom is one of the smallest operators—maybe they lack the capacity for something this scale.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And Transtelecom is one of the smallest operators-maybe they lack the capacity for something this scale.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Transtelecom JSC is one of the largest communication operators in the Republic of Kazakhstan that specialize in provision of a wide range of telecommunication services, digitalization and system integration in the field of IT, communications, automation and energy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But they plan to cover 18 villages next year, which is something, I guess. Still, the long-term vision seems shaky.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But they plan to cover eighteen villages next year, which is something, I guess. Still, the long-term vision seems shaky.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It was reported that already this year, TTC will provide 48 villages and 150 local state bodies with Internet access.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. Nadyrov called it a foundation for analog services—like they're planning for the past, not the future.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. Nadyrov called it a foundation for analog services-like they're planning for the past, not the future.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Zhanbolat Nadyrov also added that the project will be implemented with the long term prospects, so the fiber-optic infrastructure will become as the foundation for a number of future projects such as Smart schools, telemedicine and safe city.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's frustrating because internet access should bridge gaps, not deepen them. Those schools and hospitals deserve better than 5 Mbit/s.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's frustrating because internet access should bridge gaps, not deepen them. Those schools and hospitals deserve better than five megabits per second.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...which will provide 421 rural settlements and 1222 local schools, hospitals, local state bodies, police stations and other institutions with the Internet access at a high speed of 20 Mbit/s.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Let's hope there's more to the strategy, 'cause on the surface, it looks like a missed opportunity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Let's hope there's more to the strategy, 'cause on the surface, it looks like a missed opportunity.

artist_script:
HostA: So, a ten-year project to bring satellite internet to urban Kazakhstan, but the CFO, Zhanbolat Nadyrov, admits it might actually increase digital inequality?
HostB: Yeah, that’s a pretty wild contradiction, right? He straight up said rural public servants won’t benefit as much.
HostA: Exactly! And they’re running five thousand kilometers of copper wire for just 5 Mbit/s—that’s like, barely usable speed by today’s standards.
HostB: Uh-huh, and only 241 urban settlements? That feels so limited for such a huge country.
HostA: Plus, he mentioned it could negatively impact e-commerce development and digital literacy. Like, why even frame it as progress?
HostB: I mean, it’s almost like they’re building outdated infrastructure on purpose. Copper wires? In 2017?
HostA: Right? And Transtelecom is one of the smallest operators—maybe they lack the capacity for something this scale.
HostB: But they plan to cover 18 villages next year, which is something, I guess. Still, the long-term vision seems shaky.
HostA: Definitely. Nadyrov called it a foundation for analog services—like they’re planning for the past, not the future.
HostB: It’s frustrating because internet access should bridge gaps, not deepen them. Those schools and hospitals deserve better than 5 Mbit/s.
HostA: Absolutely. Let’s hope there’s more to the strategy, ‘cause on the surface, it looks like a missed opportunity.
